biography.placeOfBirth: Uman Raion, Ukrainian SSR, USSR [now Cherkasy Oblast, Ukraine]
biography.bio: Anatoli Barchuk was born on November 16, 1939 in Uman Raion, Ukrainian SSR, USSR as Anatoli Trofimovitch Barchuk. He was an actor, known for Dva goda nad propastyu (1966), Na kievskom napravlyenii (1968) and The Russian Triangle (2007). He died on June 7, 2015.
biography.name: Anatoli Barchuk

biography.placeOfBirth: Gorodishche, RSFSR, USSR [now Penza Oblast, Russia]
biography.bio: Nina Veselovskaya was born on March 7, 1937 in Gorodishche, RSFSR, USSR as Nina Valentinovna Veselovskaya. She is an actress, known for Syostry (1957), Khmuroe utro (1959) and Vosemnadtsatyy god (1958).
biography.name: Nina Veselovskaya

biography.bio: Silviya Sergeichikova was born on November 2, 1939 as Silviya Aleksandrovna Sergeichikova. She is an actress and director, known for Ta samaya noch (1969), Dva goda nad propastyu (1966) and Zhitie svyatyh sester (1982).
biography.name: Silviya Sergeichikova

biography.bio: Yekaterina Krupennikova was born on February 15, 1940 in Leningrad, USSR as Yekaterina Evgenievna Krupennikova. She is an actress, known for Khochu verit (1965), Dva goda nad propastyu (1966) and Ta samaya noch (1969).
biography.name: Yekaterina Krupennikova

biography.placeOfBirth: Zamytye, Tver Governorate, Russian Empire [now Russia]
biography.bio: Nikolai Nikolaevich Kryukov was born on July 8, 1915, in a village in Tver province, USSR. His parents were farmers. Young Kryukov was fond of silent films. In 1930, he decided to become an actor and moved to Leningrad. During the 1930s he was industrial worker at the "Sevkabel" plant in Leningrad. At that time he also attended acting class at the Bolshoi Drama Theatre (BDT) in Leningrad, graduating in 1935 as an actor. From 1936 - 1941 he was permanent member of the troupe with E. Radlov's theatre, then at Lensoveta Theatre in Leningrad. In 1940, Kryukov made his film debut in 'Politruk Kolyvanov' (1940), but the film was not completed because of the hardship in the Second World War. During WWII, Nikolai Nikolaevich Kryukov worked as actor during the siege of Leningrad. In the beginning of 1942, he was evacuated from besieged Leningrad to the city of Pyatigorsk. There he was arrested by the advancing Nazi Army and was taken to Germany as a POW. In Germany, Nikolai Nikolaevich Kryukov worked as actor until liberation at the end of WWII. Then he was returned to the Soviet Union together with five million other POWs. After the war, Nikolai Nikolaevich Kryukov undergone interrogation by the Red Army intelligence and the KGB, before he was allowed to work again as a stage actor with various theatre companies in such cities as Tbilisi, Tver, Rostov, and Riga. However, he was restricted from working in Leningrad/St. Petersburg until after the death of the Soviet dictator Joseph Stalin a series of political changes were initiated in the Soviet Union by Nikita Khrushchev. In 1958 Nikolai Kryukov returned to Leningrad and became staff actor at the Lenfilm Studios. He was regarded for his roles in such films as Andromeda Nebula (1967), Devushka i Grand (1982), and in the popular Russian series about Sherlock Holmes. Nikolai Nikolaevich Kryukov was married to actress Lilia Gurova and the couple lived in St. Petersburg, Russia. He was designated Honorable Actor of Russia (1992) and was a highly respected actor in Russia. He died of a heart failure on April 30, 1993, and was laid to rest in Serafimovskoe Cemetery in St. Petersburg, Russia.
biography.name: Nikolai Kryukov

biography.placeOfBirth: Kolchugino, Kuznetsk uyezd, Tomsk Governorate, RSFSR [now Leninsk-Kuznetsky, Kemerovo Oblast, Russia]
biography.bio: Nikolai Barmin was born on March 23, 1922 in Kolchugino, Kuznetsk uyezd, Tomsk Governorate, RSFSR as Nikolay Mikhaylovich Barmin. He was an actor, known for Father of a Soldier (1965), La Proie (1959) and Sahar (1960). He died on January 12, 1997 in Moscow, Russia.
biography.name: Nikolai Barmin

biography.bio: Viktor Chekmaryov was born on January 30, 1911 in Astrakhan, Russian Empire as Viktor Konstantinovich Csekmarev. He was an actor, known for Life in Your Hands (1959), Ugryum-reka (1969) and Troynaya proverka (1970). He died on August 22, 1987 in Leningrad, RSFSR, USSR.
biography.name: Viktor Chekmaryov

biography.placeOfBirth: Yasinovataya, Bakhmut uyezd, Yekaterinoslav Governorate, Russian Empire [now Yasynuvata Raion, Donetsk Oblast, Ukraine]
biography.bio: Nikolai Gritsenko was a notable Russian actor known for the role as Kareni in Anna Karénine (1967) by director Aleksandr Zarkhi, and as Nazi General in TV series 'Semnadtsat mgnovenii vesny' by director Tatyana Lioznova. He was born Nikolai Olimpiyevich Gritsenko on July 24, 1912, in Yasinovataya, Donetsk province, Russian Empire (now Donetsk, Ukraine). In 1934 he graduated from Makeevka School of musical drama, then studied acting in Kiev. From 1937 - 1940 he studied acting at Shchukin Theatrical School of the Vakhtangov Theatre in Moscow, graduating in 1940 as an actor. From 1940 to 1979 Nikolai Gritsenko was a permanent member of the troupe at Vakhtangov Theatre in Moscow. There his stage partners were such actors as Mikhail Ulyanov, Ruben Simonov, Boris Zakhava, Mikhail Astangov, Vladimir Etush, Varvara Popova, Irina Kupchenko, Natalya Tenyakova, Yuliya Borisova, Lyudmila Maksakova, Lyudmila Tselikovskaya, Marianna Vertinskaya, Nina Ruslanova, Nikolai Plotnikov, Vasiliy Lanovoy, Yuriy Yakovlev, Vyacheslav Shalevich, Andrei Abrikosov, Grigori Abrikosov, Boris Babochkin, Nikolai Timofeyev, Aleksandr Grave, and Evgeniy Karelskikh, among others. His most memorable stage performances were such roles as Fedor Protasov in "Zhivoy Trup" (1962) (aka.. The Living Corpse) after the eponymous novel by Leo Tolstoy, and the title role as Prince Myshkin in Dostoyevsky's "Idiot" (1958). Gritsenko created the role as Tartalya in 'Princess Turandot' (1963), and delivered many acclaimed performances in the legendary Vakhtangov's production of Carlo Gozzi's comedy. Nikolai Gritsenko was designated People's Actor of the USSR (1964). He was awarded the State Prize of Russia for his stage work, and was awarded the State Prize of the USSR (1951) for his role in the film Dream of a Cossack (1951). He died of a heart failure on December 8, 1979, in Moscow, Russia, Soviet Union, and was laid to rest in the Novodevichy Cemetery in Moscow, Russia.
biography.name: Nikolai Gritsenko

biography.placeOfBirth: Nizhny Novgorod, Russian SFSR, USSR [now Russia]
biography.bio: Lyudmila Khityaeva was born on August 5, 1930 in Nizhny Novgorod, Russian SFSR, USSR as Lyudmila Ivanovna Khityayeva. She is an actress, known for Evdokiya (1961), Ekaterina Voronina (1957) and The Night Before Christmas (1962).
biography.name: Lyudmila Khityaeva

biography.placeOfBirth: Magnitogorsk, Chelyabinsk Oblast, Russian SFSR, USSR [now Russia]
biography.bio: Irina Bunina was born on August 17, 1939 in Magnitogorsk, Chelyabinsk Oblast, Russian SFSR, USSR as Irina Alekseyevna Bunina. She is an actress, known for Moi lyudi (1990), Artist iz Kokhanovki (1962) and Verte mne, lyudi (1965).
biography.name: Irina Bunina

biography.placeOfBirth: Tiflis, Georgian SSR, TSFSR [now Tbilisi, Republic of Georgia]
biography.bio: Gurgen Tonunts was born on September 2, 1922 in Tiflis, Georgian SSR, TSFSR as Gurgen Oganesovich Tonunts. He was an actor, known for An Extraordinary Assignment (1966), They Are to Live (1960) and The Last Deed of Kamo (1974). He died on September 21, 1997 in Moscow, Russia.
biography.name: Gurgen Tonunts

biography.bio: Harijs Liepins was born on March 15, 1927 in Riga, Latvia. He was an actor, known for Akmens un skembas (1966), Zolotoy eshelon (1959) and Davanas pa telefonu (1977). He died on August 3, 1998 in Riga.
biography.name: Harijs Liepins

biography.placeOfBirth: Podolsk, Podolsk uyezd, Moscow Governorate, Russian Empire [now Podolsky District, Moscow Oblast, Russia]
biography.bio: Mikhail Sidorkin was born on February 4, 1910 in Podolsk, Podolsk uyezd, Moscow Governorate, Russian Empire as Mikhail Nikolaevitch Sidorkin. He was an actor, known for Spring (1947), Symphony of Life (1948) and The Vow (1946). He died on April 1, 1980 in Moscow, RSFSR, USSR.
biography.name: Mikhail Sidorkin
